definition: to fill/to satisfy/to fulfill/to act in place of/substitute/sufficient/full
texture/grain (of wood)/inner essence/intrinsic order/reason/logic/truth/science/natural science (esp. physics)/to manage/to pay attention to/to run (affairs)/to handle/to put in order/to tidy up
to follow/from/it is for...to/reason/cause/because of/due to/to/to leave it (to sb)/by (introduces passive verb)
circular argument/logical error consisting of begging the question/Latin: petitio principii
dialectics/dialectic or Socratic method of debate
epistemology (in philosophy, the theory of how we know things)
pluralism, philosophical doctrine that the universe consists of different substances
Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (1770-1831), German philosopher
dualism, belief that the universe is made of two different substance (e.g. mind and matter or good and evil)
philosophy of idealism, the doctrine that external reality is a product of consciousness
voluntarism/metaphysical view, esp. due to Schopenhauer 叔本華|叔本华[Shu1 ben3 hua2], that the essence of the world is willpower
